channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Katie Britt, a former lobbyist and chief of staff to Senator Richard Shelby, defeated Representative Mo Brooks in a runoff for the Republican nomination in the open Senate race in Alabama. https://t.co/tJqISD3Pg7
South Dakota’s Senate voted to remove the attorney general, Jason Ravnsborg, from office after he fatally struck a man with his car in 2020. https://t.co/jKOCjZW6eZ

Breaking News: State Rep. Bee Nguyen has won the Democratic nomination for Georgia secretary of state. She will face the incumbent Brad Raffensperger in the November general election. https://t.co/Ya5pLf6lhF
Breaking News: A jury in California found that Bill Cosby sexually assaulted a 16-year-old girl in 1975 and awarded her $500,000 in damages. https://t.co/eSF7fAIa8e

Under arcane rules, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen’s signature couldn’t appear on the dollar until a treasurer was in place. On Tuesday, President Biden named Marilynn Malerba as U.S. treasurer. She will be the first Native American to hold the position. https://t.co/cYuGSDN0Dc

A giant stingray, hauled out of the Mekong River in Cambodia, measured 13 feet in length and weighed 661 pounds. It’s thought to be the world’s largest freshwater fish.
The find is a positive sign of the health of the river, which faces many challenges. https://t.co/54YEWiQ6dA https://t.co/9isqEWbipe

The Jan. 6 committee sought on Tuesday to show that Donald Trump’s false claims of election fraud were a significant threat to the U.S. election system and democracy itself — putting sharp focus on the pressure officials faced to overturn the 2020 results. https://t.co/3ImshKbptW https://t.co/8RlWUd1wW9

Rusty Bowers, a Republican and Arizona’s House speaker, described the pressure campaign he faced to overturn his state’s 2020 election results. "I will not play with laws I swore allegiance to," he wrote in a journal entry that he read to the Jan. 6 panel. https://t.co/1VDVIOhonN
Breaking News: The Supreme Court rejected Maine’s ban on state aid for religious schools in its latest decision favoring religious interests. https://t.co/ipE46mWKRE

A Nobel Peace Prize medal put up for auction by a Russian journalist to help Ukrainian child refugees sold for $103.5 million to an anonymous buyer.
Dmitri Muratov will donate the proceeds to UNICEF. https://t.co/JQNQaQoUW5

Breaking News: The head of Texas' state police called the police response to the Uvalde shooting "an abject failure" that ran counter to decades of training. He said officers wasted time looking for a classroom door key that was "never needed." https://t.co/TreJ8yJfPV

Russia’s ruble hit a seven-year high, cementing its status as the world’s best-performing currency.
It has gained about 35% so far this year, and has more than doubled from a low after the invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/fPA689PnyY

Health experts will call on Tuesday for an overhaul of the U.S. public health system that would expand the role of the federal government, giving Washington the authority to set minimum health standards and coordinate a patchwork of nearly 3,000 agencies. https://t.co/M4OUsrVeCU
Breaking News: Merrick Garland, the U.S. attorney general, traveled to Ukraine to discuss the prosecution of Russians for war crimes, his spokesman said. https://t.co/Fc1rhlmPlC

Moscow threatened Lithuania with retaliation if it did not quickly reverse a ban on the rail transportation of some goods to Kaliningrad, a landlocked Russian region. The restrictions are a response to European sanctions, a Lithuanian official said. https://t.co/rPIEQiQVf5

The New York Times studied China’s surveillance capabilities by examining more than 100,000 government bidding documents.
China’s ambition to collect personal data is more expansive and invasive than previously known, our investigation found. https://t.co/I56kVq7n4p
Thousands of Ukrainians were taken to “filtration camps” and forced to resettle in Russia. Some escaped. These are their stories. https://t.co/7ZKBdjbray https://t.co/8xttsQXC3B

A Nobel Peace Prize medal put up for auction by a Russian journalist to help Ukrainian child refugees sold for $103.5 million to an anonymous buyer.
Dimitri Muratov will donate the proceeds to UNICEF. https://t.co/OaSVCKPcfe https://t.co/n7M5G5ZBWU
Stress can take a serious toll on mental and physical health. New research suggests that certain types of stress can even age your immune system. https://t.co/CldaWRLf38

The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol attack will also underscore the vitriol and suffering that election workers endured because of former President Trump’s pressure campaign to subvert the will of voters. https://t.co/uSoPJ8JXyh

A Nobel Peace Prize medal put up for auction by a Russian journalist to help Ukrainian child refugees sold for $103.5 million to an anonymous buyer.
Dimitri Muratov will donate the proceeds to UNICEF. https://t.co/X9RYQmwB47

The Russian blockade that has stopped Ukraine from exporting its vast storehouses of grain and other goods, threatening starvation in some countries, is a “war crime,” the EU’s top foreign policy official declared. https://t.co/AVKKjjBCRX

Gustavo Petro, exrebelde y senador con experiencia, gana la segunda vuelta en Colombia y se convertirá en el primer presidente de izquierda del país. Los resultados ponen al tercer país más poblado de América Latina en un rumbo muy distinto. https://t.co/pUvSJ9xcfD
Bears Ears in Utah will become the first national monument to be jointly managed by the U.S. government and Native American tribes. https://t.co/Nil2Xy16pd

Germany will restart coal-fired power plants in order to conserve natural gas, the country’s economy minister announced. The move comes amid concerns about a looming supply shortage after Russia cut gas deliveries to Europe. https://t.co/gDmTzYDxtP

Hundreds of thousands of Ukrainians have been forcibly removed and pressured to take Russian citizenship.
The New York Times traveled to Estonia to speak to Ukrainian refugees who survived the siege of Mariupol and were then forced to resettle in Russia. https://t.co/DRlRygfUz6 https://t.co/BzcqgpgCJ8

The Black Sea blockade that is preventing Ukraine from exporting food and other goods is a “war crime” and Russia will be held accountable if it continues, the EU’s foreign policy chief said. https://t.co/cGixzzyYzB

A New York Times investigation found that the bullet that killed Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian American journalist, was fired from the approximate location of an Israeli military convoy — most likely by a soldier from an elite unit. https://t.co/QWZOfMTWsk

Eric Greitens, a Republican candidate for the Senate in Missouri, released a violent new political ad showing himself with a shotgun accompanying a team of heavily armed men as they storm a home in search of “RINOs,” or Republicans in name only. https://t.co/IP8FCHKAJm

Francia Márquez, an environmental activist, became a phenomenon in Colombia, mobilizing decades of voter frustration. She became the country’s first Black vice president on Sunday.
Photo: Federico Rios for The New York Times https://t.co/KbxQ2O87Wp https://t.co/sgCRSX0Usu

Russia surpassed Saudi Arabia to become China’s largest source of petroleum in May, as Chinese companies stepped in to buy oil that has fallen under widening Western sanctions. https://t.co/OgYJHjPxsE

An Ethiopian rebel group massacred more than 200 members of the Amhara ethnic group on Sunday, according to officials and news reports. The killings were the latest to roil the country, which is reeling from a civil war that began almost two years ago. https://t.co/W0zzNn2GX2

Colombia tendrá un presidente de izquierda por primera vez. Gustavo Petro, un exguerrillero y senador experimentado que se ha comprometido a transformar el sistema económico del país, ganó las elecciones del domingo. https://t.co/tcr0Coj4ZA

Germany will restart coal-fired power plants in order to conserve natural gas, the country’s economy minister announced. The move comes amid concerns about a looming supply shortage after Russia cut gas deliveries to Europe. https://t.co/tgp46vFAlc

Colombia will have a leftist president for the first time. Gustavo Petro, a former rebel and a longtime senator, won the country's election on Sunday, galvanizing voters frustrated by decades of poverty and inequality under conservative leaders. https://t.co/5oyEH0eDM6

Young, mostly female activists, many from Eastern Europe, believe that the Ukraine war is a brutal demonstration of the world’s dependence on fossil fuels. They are cornering Europe’s leaders and pressing them for a total energy embargo on Russia. https://t.co/vIUv6VHhCQ

A New York Times investigation found that the bullet that killed Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian American journalist, was fired from the approximate location of an Israeli military convoy — most likely by a soldier from an elite unit. https://t.co/zHh33rknVT
The Republican Party in Texas approved an official platform that included the claim that President Biden was not legitimately elected. https://t.co/CRaxijOppv

With Roe v. Wade expected to end, women with high-risk pregnancies and their doctors are agonizing over what bar they would need to clear to legally justify an abortion in some states.
“How almost dead does someone need to be?” one physician asked. https://t.co/Nt1UsU6hkK

A 15-year-old boy was killed and three adults, including a police officer, were shot at an unauthorized music event known as Moechella in Washington, D.C., the authorities said. The police did not initially say whether a suspect or suspects were in custody.https://t.co/aLMorikx63

A Times analysis found that Russian forces have pummeled Ukraine with a barrage of rockets and other munitions, most of which can be considered relatively crude relics of the Cold War, and many of which have been banned widely under international treaties. https://t.co/thXyRn01P6

Gustavo Petro, a former rebel and longtime senator, won Colombia's election and will become the country's first leftist president.
"This story that we are writing today is a new story for Colombia, for Latin America, for the world," he said. https://t.co/JzvvzpswvP https://t.co/ZTA6LjTsBR

On Father's Day in Ukraine, President Volodymyr Zelensky praised the fathers who had offered their service to the country, while children of fallen soldiers spent the day in new grief. https://t.co/VNbwutP6Nk

Before the Civil War, a predominantly Black community flourished in Seneca Village — on the land that is now Central Park.
To commemorate Juneteenth on Sunday, Black artists performed in the park to tell the story of life in that village. https://t.co/6spY2dc6iu
More than 200 people were killed in Ethiopia, witnesses there said on Sunday, in an attack in the Oromia region that they said targeted mostly ethnic Amhara people. https://t.co/LGmJarRojI

The GOP worked for years to tilt the Supreme Court against climate action. Within days, a ruling could raise the stakes by severely limiting the federal government’s authority to reduce carbon dioxide from power plants.
But it’s only a start. https://t.co/RdzhiCD5Jy https://t.co/3o2AAjFZGp

Long before Gustavo Petro emerged as the apparently victorious leftist candidate for Colombia's president, he was part of the M-19, an urban guerrilla group. For some voters, his past was a source of concern. For others, it offered a sign of hope. https://t.co/hBrvlX7keL

Breaking News: For the first time, Colombia will have a leftist president. Gustavo Petro, a former rebel and a longtime senator who has pledged to transform the country’s economic system, has won Sunday’s election, according to preliminary results. https://t.co/ZpbMmUCIyl

Workers at a Baltimore-area Apple store celebrated on Saturday after roughly two-thirds of its employees voted to unionize, making it the first of the company’s 270-plus stores in the U.S. to do so. https://t.co/poCJIJ6rQv https://t.co/oQdN5D6I55

Breaking News: FINA, the international swimming federation, announced Sunday that it is barring transgender women from competing in women's competitions if they have gone through male puberty. https://t.co/5gL6dDTfkH
